title: Methodology: Spatial Capabilities and INLA
text:
The core conceptual model of this theoretical framework is the capabilities approach which provides a powerful lens for understanding how place-based factors influence criminal justice outcomes. Our theoretical framework integrates the capabilities process with spatial analysis to understand how geographic context shapes the translation of resources into actual opportunities.

    end

        direction LR
        R["Resources"] -->|converted by| CF
        CF -->|enable| CAP["Capabilities"]
        CAP -->|achieve| F["Functionings"]
    end

    subgraph CO["Community Outcomes"]
        direction TB

        F -->|supports| CI["Community Integration"]

    style CP fill:#fff0f3,stroke:#333,stroke-width:4px
    style CO fill:#f0fff4,stroke:#333,stroke-width:4px













Three Fundamental Elements



1. Conversion Factors: The mechanisms that translate resources into actual capabilities


Personal: Skills, health status, trauma history, decision-making capacity

Social: Community norms, social networks, cultural context, power relations


Environmental: Infrastructure, institutions, geographic location, environmental conditions

2. Capability Sets: The actual freedoms and opportunities available to individuals


Social Capabilities: Community integration, cultural connection, civic participation

Economic Capabilities: Employment access, skill development, financial stability

Health Capabilities: Treatment access, wellness management, healthcare navigation

3. Spatial Embedding: How capabilities develop and cluster geographically


Collective capabilities that emerge through community-level processes

Cross-boundary spillovers between neighboring communities

Place-based constraints and opportunities








Figure 2: Neighborhood Effects Framework - How Place Shapes Capabilities



The neighborhood effects framework illustrates how residential segregation by race/ethnicity and socioeconomic status creates differential access to capability-enhancing resources. This process operates through:



Environmental exposures (air quality, pollution, hazards)

Food and recreational resources (access to healthy options, safe spaces)

Built environment quality (housing, infrastructure, transportation)

Aesthetic quality and natural spaces (parks, green space, community appearance)



Safety and violence (community safety, exposure to trauma)

Social connections and cohesion (collective efficacy, social capital)

Local institutions (schools, healthcare, community organizations)

Culture and norms (community values, expectations, social control)

The pathway from neighborhood conditions to outcomes operates through stress and behavioral mediators, highlighting how environmental conditions get ‚Äúunder the skin‚Äù to affect individual functioning and decision-making.

title: Abstract
text: This study employs the Integrated Nested Laplace Approximation (INLA) Bayesian methods to analyze the spatial distribution of community punishment across Utah from 2016-2023, examining how systems of punishment intersect with place-based capability deprivations. While traditional studies of community punishment have focused on metropolitan areas, recent evidence suggests that most correctional system involvement now originates from non-metropolitan regions - including small cities, towns, and rural areas, which comprise most of Utah‚Äôs geography. Using data from Utah‚Äôs Department of Corrections, this paper develops a Bayesian hierarchical model grounded in the capabilities approach from feminist economics to examine how the spatial distribution of community punishment relates to social provisioning and institutional capacity. The analysis explores how capability deprivations - including restricted access to healthcare, economic opportunities, public safety resources, transportation, and social services - are structurally embedded in place and shape community-level criminal justice outcomes. The INLA methodology allows for robust estimation of spatial random effects while accounting for the complex neighborhood structure of these capability constraints across Utah‚Äôs diverse geography. This feminist economic framework, combined with spatial Bayesian modeling, provides critical insights for evidence-based policy-making by identifying how place-based deprivations of capabilities interact with systems of community punishment. The findings suggest that spatial heterogeneity in social provisioning plays a crucial role in shaping community corrections outcomes, with important implications for addressing structural inequities through place-based policy interventions across Utah‚Äôs criminal justice and social provisioning system.

What This Section Accomplishes: This section creates the primary outcome variable - correctional population rate per 1,000 residents - by aggregating individual supervision records to the census tract level. The process calculates standardized rates that allow for meaningful comparison across tracts with different population sizes. Additionally, expected counts are computed for use in Poisson regression modeling, accounting for varying tract populations in the statistical analysis.

2.3.2 3.3.2 Explanatory Variable Integration
What This Section Accomplishes: This step assembles predictor variables from multiple data sources representing different theoretical domains of the capabilities framework. Variables include demographic characteristics from the American Community Survey, environmental measures from the Utah Healthy Places Index, and healthcare access indicators from the GeoDa Center database. The integration creates a comprehensive set of potential conversion factors that may influence correctional population patterns across neighborhoods.

2.3.3 3.3.3 Final Dataset Construction
What This Section Accomplishes: This section merges all data sources into a single analysis-ready dataset and creates standardized versions of key variables for modeling. The process ensures data quality through coverage assessment and creates the spatial identifiers needed for spatial modeling. The result is a comprehensive dataset with 98.7% coverage across Utah census tracts, containing both the outcome variable and all potential predictor variables.

text:
2.1 4.1 Model Specification

2.1.1 Mathematical Framework
The INLA-BYM2 model for correctional supervision counts follows:
\[y_i \sim \text{Poisson}(\mu_i)\]
\[\log(\mu_i) = \log(E_i) + \alpha + \sum_{j=1}^p \beta_j x_{ij} + u_i + v_i\]

The BYM2 model decomposes spatial variation:
\[u_i = \frac{1}{\sqrt{\tau_u}}(\sqrt{\phi} \cdot z_i + \sqrt{1-\phi} \cdot \epsilon_i)\]

\(z_i\): Spatially structured component (collective capabilities)

title: Theoretical Foundation
text:
The contemporary criminal justice landscape presents a fundamental challenge that traditional approaches have failed to address effectively. With nearly 5.5 million adults under correctional control nationally‚Äîincluding 3.7 million under community supervision‚Äîthe United States has created what can only be described as a system of ‚Äúmass corrections.‚Äù In Utah specifically, this translates to 16,300 adults under community supervision compared to only 5,900 in state prisons, representing a nearly 3:1 ratio that has grown substantially in recent years.
This empirical reality demands a theoretical framework that moves beyond individual-focused explanations to understand how place-based factors shape criminal justice outcomes. As Keels (2020) observes, ‚ÄúAmerican society tends to pour money and resources into punishment when victims become perpetrators, even though aggression, substance abuse, and other symptoms targeted as problematic behaviors by the legal system are often coping strategies to increase safety and security in individuals with histories of trauma.‚Äù This insight points toward the need for an approach that understands correctional involvement not as individual failure, but as a manifestation of broader capability deprivations embedded in geographic space.
The complexity of this challenge becomes apparent when we consider the population characteristics of those under correctional supervision. Research by Western (2015) reveals the concept of ‚Äúhuman frailty‚Äù among justice-involved populations: 67% have mental illness or addiction histories, 40% witnessed violence before age 18, and 40% experienced family custody loss. These multiple, interacting challenges suggest that effective interventions must address not just individual deficits, but the place-based conversion factors that determine whether available resources translate into actual capabilities for successful community integration.

2.1 From Resources to Capabilities: A Fundamental Distinction
Traditional criminal justice policy operates on an implicit assumption that providing resources‚Äîwhether treatment programs, job training, or housing assistance‚Äîwill directly translate into improved outcomes. This resource-focused approach, however, ignores the crucial insight from capabilities theory (Sen 1999; Nussbaum 2000): resources ‚â† opportunities. The translation from resources to actual capabilities depends fundamentally on conversion factors that operate at multiple scales and are deeply embedded in geographic space.
Consider the difference between having a substance abuse treatment program located in a community (a resource) versus individuals actually being able to access, engage with, and benefit from that program (a capability). The conversion from resource to capability depends on transportation accessibility, cultural appropriateness of services, community stigma, family support systems, and numerous other factors that cluster spatially and interact in complex ways.

The FARS domains‚Äîranging from biological factors like depression and medical conditions, to psychological factors like anxiety and traumatic stress, to social factors like work/school functioning and legal status‚Äîrepresent the observable manifestations of underlying capability processes.

2.2.1 Conversion Factors: The Mechanisms of Capability Formation
Personal Conversion Factors operate at the individual level but are shaped by place-based experiences across the life course. Skills and abilities develop through educational opportunities that vary dramatically by neighborhood. Health status reflects both individual choices and environmental exposures‚Äîfrom air quality to food access to healthcare availability. Trauma history accumulates through exposure to community violence, family instability, and institutional failures that cluster geographically. Even decision-making capacity develops through socialization processes embedded in local cultural contexts.
Social Conversion Factors emerge through community-level processes that cannot be reduced to individual characteristics. Community attitudes toward criminal justice involvement shape whether returning citizens face acceptance or rejection. Social networks provide information about employment opportunities, housing options, and service availability‚Äîbut these networks are geographically bounded and reflect local resource availability. Cultural context determines whether seeking help is viewed as appropriate or stigmatized. Power relations embedded in local political and economic structures determine whose voices are heard in policy decisions affecting community safety and support.
Environmental Conversion Factors represent the most clearly spatial dimensions of capability formation. Infrastructure quality‚Äîfrom transportation systems to broadband access‚Äîdetermines whether individuals can access opportunities located elsewhere. Institutional capacity reflects the accumulated investment in schools, healthcare facilities, community organizations, and government services that has occurred over decades. Geographic location itself matters, as peripheral or isolated communities face inherent barriers to accessing resources concentrated in urban centers. Environmental conditions, from air and water quality to noise and pollution exposure, create differential health impacts that compound over time.

2.2.2 Capability Sets: The Actual Freedoms Available
The integration of personal, social, and environmental conversion factors produces capability sets‚Äîthe actual freedoms and opportunities available to individuals in particular places. These capabilities cluster into domains that map directly onto criminal justice outcomes:
Social Capabilities encompass community integration, cultural connection, and civic participation. These capabilities develop through repeated positive interactions within community contexts that either welcome or exclude particular groups. High-capability communities provide multiple pathways for social connection and civic engagement, while low-capability communities may lack the institutional infrastructure necessary to support meaningful participation.
Economic Capabilities include employment access, skill development, and financial stability. These capabilities depend not just on individual human capital, but on local labor markets, transportation systems, and the geographic distribution of economic opportunities. Communities with strong economic capabilities provide multiple pathways to financial stability, while economically isolated communities offer few legitimate opportunities for economic advancement.
Health Capabilities involve treatment access, wellness management, and healthcare navigation. These capabilities reflect both individual health status and community health infrastructure. High-capability communities provide accessible, culturally appropriate healthcare options and promote community wellness through environmental quality and health-promoting built environments.

2.2.3 Spatial Embedding and Collective Capabilities
Perhaps most importantly for criminal justice policy, capabilities are not just individually held but develop collectively within geographic communities. Collective capabilities emerge through community-level processes that enhance or constrain individual capability development. These include:


Institutional capacity that determines service availability and quality

Social cohesion that facilitates information sharing and mutual support

Collective efficacy that enables communities to address shared problems

Environmental quality that provides the foundation for healthy development

2.3 Understanding Neighborhood Effects Through a Capabilities Lens
The neighborhood effects framework provides crucial insight into how residential segregation by race/ethnicity and socioeconomic status creates systematic inequalities in capability formation. This process operates through multiple, interacting pathways that compound over time and across generations.




Figure 2: Neighborhood Effects Framework - How Place Shapes Capabilities




2.3.1 Physical Environment Pathways: Environmental Conversion Factors
The physical environment represents perhaps the most direct manifestation of how place shapes capabilities. Environmental exposures create differential health impacts that accumulate over the life course. Communities experiencing poor air quality‚Äîas our Utah analysis reveals with diesel particulate matter‚Äîface 494.7% higher correctional supervision rates, suggesting that environmental conditions act as powerful conversion factors constraining multiple capabilities simultaneously.
Food and recreational resources determine whether communities can support healthy development. Food deserts limit nutritional capability development, while lack of safe recreational spaces constrains physical activity and positive social interaction. The built environment quality‚Äîfrom housing conditions to infrastructure adequacy‚Äîprovides the basic foundation upon which other capabilities develop.
Aesthetic quality and natural spaces may seem secondary to immediate survival needs, but research consistently demonstrates their importance for mental health, community pride, and social cohesion. Communities with well-maintained parks, tree canopy coverage, and attractive public spaces provide environments that support positive identity formation and community attachment.

2.3.2 Social Environment Pathways: Social Conversion Factors
The social environment operates through mechanisms that are less visible but equally powerful in shaping capability formation. Safety and violence exposure creates trauma that affects cognitive development, educational achievement, and social functioning across the life course. Communities with high violence rates constrain mobility, limit social interaction, and create chronic stress that affects decision-making capacity.
Social connections and cohesion provide the interpersonal infrastructure necessary for capability development. Strong social networks facilitate information sharing about opportunities, provide emotional support during crises, and create accountability mechanisms that promote positive behavior. Our analysis shows that communities with higher census response rates‚Äîa proxy for collective efficacy‚Äîhave 73.6% lower correctional supervision rates, demonstrating the protective power of social capital.
Local institutions serve as the formal infrastructure for capability development. Schools, healthcare facilities, community organizations, and faith-based institutions provide both direct services and spaces for social connection. However, institutional capacity varies dramatically across communities based on historical investment patterns and current resource availability.
Culture and norms create the informal rules that guide behavior and define what kinds of futures seem possible. Communities with strong norms supporting education, employment, and family stability provide cultural resources that promote capability development, while communities where legitimate opportunities appear unavailable may develop oppositional cultures that can lead to criminal justice involvement.

2.3.3 Individual and Behavioral Mediators: The Pathway ‚ÄúUnder the Skin‚Äù
The pathway from neighborhood conditions to individual outcomes operates through stress and behavioral mediators that represent how environmental conditions get ‚Äúunder the skin‚Äù to affect individual functioning. Chronic exposure to environmental stressors‚Äîfrom pollution to violence to economic instability‚Äîcreates physiological and psychological changes that affect decision-making capacity, emotional regulation, and social functioning.
This understanding is crucial for criminal justice policy because it suggests that what appears to be individual criminal behavior often reflects adaptive responses to constraint environments. Rather than viewing criminal behavior as evidence of individual moral failure, a capabilities approach understands it as a symptom of systematic capability deprivation embedded in place-based processes.

2.3.4 Why Spatial Analysis Matters
Traditional criminal justice research focuses on individual factors, but the capabilities approach suggests that place-based conversion factors may be equally or more important:


Geographic clustering of opportunities and constraints

Cross-boundary spillovers between neighboring communities

Collective capabilities that emerge through community-level processes

Environmental justice concerns affecting capability formation

title: Introduction
text:
The landscape of mass incarceration in the United States has undergone a profound transformation over the past three decades, fundamentally challenging conventional narratives about where and how criminal justice system involvement occurs. Contrary to popular frameworks that position mass incarceration as primarily an urban phenomenon concentrated in racially segregated inner-city neighborhoods, emerging evidence reveals a dramatic spatial redistribution of correctional system involvement toward non-metropolitan regions, including small cities, towns, and rural areas (Kang-Brown & Subramanian, 2017; Simes, 2021). This geographic transformation represents not merely a shift in the location of punishment, but a fundamental restructuring of how systems of social control operate across America‚Äôs diverse landscape.


Recent research demonstrates that the majority of jail and prison admissions now originate from non-metropolitan regions, with the highest incarceration rates emerging across thousands of smaller cities, towns, and rural areas since the late 1990s (Simes, 2021). This pattern challenges the urban theory of crime that has dominated criminological thinking, which centers on concentrated disadvantage in racially segregated urban neighborhoods characterized by poverty, unemployment, violence, and social disorder. While these urban dynamics remain important, they represent only part of a much larger and more complex geography of punishment that extends into what Simes (2021) terms ‚ÄúAmerica‚Äôs forgotten places.‚Äù
The data reveal striking patterns of this spatial transformation. Rural counties experienced a 436 percent increase in pretrial detention rates between 1970 and 2013, growing from 49 per 100,000 people to 265 per 100,000 people (Kang-Brown et al., 2017). Simultaneously, while urban areas have benefited from criminal justice reforms and public investment in alternative services‚Äîmental health programs, diversion initiatives, and community-based interventions‚Äîrural regions have received fragmented public investment and have been largely neglected in policy dialogue. The result is an almost universal urban-to-rural shift in prison admissions across the 35 states with reliable county-level data, regardless of whether overall state admissions are declining.




This geographic transformation has been accompanied by significant demographic changes that further challenge conventional understandings of who experiences criminal justice system involvement. Small counties, including rural areas, have been driving the incarceration of women, with the number of women in jail increasing by 43 percent in rural counties and 29 percent in small and medium metropolitan counties between 2004 and 2014, while declining by 6 percent in urban counties. Similarly, the incarceration of white people grew most dramatically in rural counties‚Äî19 percent in rural counties and 15 percent in small and medium metro counties‚Äîwhile declining 15 percent in urban counties.
These demographic shifts reflect broader socioeconomic transformations affecting non-metropolitan areas, including the suburbanization of poverty, deindustrialization, disinvestment in social services, the opioid and methamphetamine epidemics, rising rates of ‚Äúdeaths of despair‚Äù (Case & Deaton, 2015), untreated mental illness, limited access to public goods, selective out-migration, social isolation, and rising unemployment and underemployment. This constellation of conditions has given rise to what scholars term the ‚Äúrural ghetto‚Äù‚Äîareas abandoned by both private capital and public investment that share qualities with urban ghettos due to high levels of segregation and stigmatization.



Equally significant is the transformation from a system focused primarily on incarceration to one increasingly reliant on community supervision. Currently, 5.5 million adults (1 in 61) are under some form of correctional control, with 3.7 million under community supervision through parole and probation‚Äîcreating a nearly 2:1 ratio of community supervision to incarceration nationwide. This shift toward ‚Äúmass corrections‚Äù represents a fundamental change in how punishment operates across space, moving beyond the bounded geography of prisons and jails to encompass the communities where individuals live, work, and attempt to rebuild their lives. This transformation has profound implications for understanding punishment as a spatial phenomenon. Unlike incarceration, which concentrates individuals in specific institutional locations, community supervision spreads across the landscape, embedding criminal justice system involvement within the fabric of communities. The effectiveness of community supervision thus depends not only on individual compliance but on the capacity of communities to provide the resources, opportunities, and support systems necessary for successful reintegration. This creates a complex geography of capability and constraint that varies dramatically across different types of places.

2.1 Geographic Concentration and Capability Deprivation
These patterns suggest that correctional supervision in Utah, as elsewhere, is not randomly distributed across space but concentrates in areas characterized by multiple forms of capability deprivation. This geographic concentration reflects not simply the aggregation of individual disadvantages but the creation of spatial contexts where the conversion factors necessary to translate resources into actual capabilities operate less effectively. Understanding these patterns requires moving beyond individual-focused explanations to examine how place-based factors shape the capacity for human development and successful community integration.
The spatial concentration of correctional populations reveals fundamental questions about how systems of punishment interact with patterns of social provisioning, institutional capacity, and community capability. Traditional approaches to criminal justice focus primarily on individual-level interventions‚Äîcounseling, job training, substance abuse treatment‚Äîwithout adequate attention to the spatial contexts within which these interventions occur. This oversight represents not merely a technical limitation but a fundamental misunderstanding of how human capabilities develop through the complex interaction of individual characteristics, social relationships, and environmental conditions across different places.

text:
3.1 RQ 1:
How do capability deprivations manifest spatially across Utah communities, and what does this reveal about the geographic distribution of resources, opportunities, and conversion factors necessary for human development?
This question examines the fundamental premise that capabilities‚Äîthe actual freedoms and opportunities individuals have to achieve the lives they value‚Äîare not randomly distributed across space but concentrate in patterns that reflect broader systems of social provisioning and institutional capacity. Drawing on Robeyns‚Äô capabilities framework from feminist economics, we conceptualize these spatial patterns as evidence of systematic inequalities in the conversion factors that enable individuals and communities to translate available resources into actual capabilities for human flourishing.
The analysis will map the geographic distribution of capability deprivations across Utah‚Äôs diverse landscape, from urban cores to rural counties, examining how access to healthcare, educational opportunities, economic development, environmental quality, transportation infrastructure, and social services varies across space. This spatial analysis of capabilities goes beyond simple resource availability to examine how place-based factors influence the effectiveness with which resources can be converted into actual freedoms and opportunities.

text:
3.2 RQ 2:
What is the spatial relationship between community corrections populations and capability deprivations, and how do place-based factors serve as conversion factors that influence correctional supervision outcomes?
This question shifts focus from patterns to relationships, examining how the geographic distribution of correctional supervision correlates with and is potentially influenced by spatial patterns of capability deprivation. The analysis moves beyond individual-level explanations for criminal justice system involvement to examine how community-level factors‚Äîwhat the capabilities approach terms ‚Äúsocial conversion factors‚Äù‚Äîshape the likelihood of supervision and the success of community reintegration efforts.
The investigation will examine multiple categories of place-based conversion factors:

Environmental Factors: Air quality, environmental hazards, green space access, and built environment conditions that affect health, wellbeing, and community capacity
Social Provisioning Factors: Healthcare access, educational opportunities, social services availability, and institutional capacity that support human development
Economic Factors: Employment opportunities, transportation access, business development, and economic infrastructure that enable economic capability formation
Social Cohesion Factors: Community engagement, collective efficacy, social networks, and civic participation that support collective capability development

text:
3.3 RQ 3:
How can Integrated Nested Laplace Approximation (INLA) methods inform the development of evidence-based, place-based policy interventions that address capability deprivations and improve community corrections outcomes?
This question addresses the critical challenge of translating spatial analysis into actionable policy guidance. Traditional policy approaches in criminal justice rely heavily on individual-level interventions without adequate tools for understanding how place-based factors influence intervention effectiveness or how to design coordinated place-based responses to complex social challenges.
The analysis will demonstrate how INLA‚Äôs Bayesian framework can provide the analytical foundation for evidence-based place-based policy development through:

Geographic Targeting: Using spatial risk assessment and uncertainty quantification to identify priority areas for intervention
Resource Allocation: Employing posterior probability distributions to optimize resource distribution under conditions of uncertainty and competing priorities
Intervention Coordination: Analyzing spatial spillover effects to design interventions that account for cross-boundary dynamics and regional interconnections
Policy Evaluation: Establishing frameworks for monitoring intervention impacts and supporting adaptive management of place-based initiatives

title: Abstract
text: This study employs the Integrated Nested Laplace Approximation (INLA) Bayesian methods to analyze the spatial distribution of community punishment across Utah from 2016-2023, examining how systems of punishment intersect with place-based capability deprivations. While traditional studies of community punishment have focused on metropolitan areas, recent evidence suggests that most correctional system involvement now originates from non-metropolitan regions - including small cities, towns, and rural areas, which comprise most of Utah‚Äôs geography. Using data from Utah‚Äôs Department of Corrections, this paper develops a Bayesian hierarchical model grounded in the capabilities approach from feminist economics to examine how the spatial distribution of community punishment relates to social provisioning and institutional capacity. The analysis explores how capability deprivations - including restricted access to healthcare, economic opportunities, public safety resources, transportation, and social services - are structurally embedded in place and shape community-level criminal justice outcomes. The INLA methodology allows for robust estimation of spatial random effects while accounting for the complex neighborhood structure of these capability constraints across Utah‚Äôs diverse geography. This feminist economic framework, combined with spatial Bayesian modeling, provides critical insights for evidence-based policy-making by identifying how place-based deprivations of capabilities interact with systems of community punishment. The findings suggest that spatial heterogeneity in social provisioning plays a crucial role in shaping community corrections outcomes, with important implications for addressing structural inequities through place-based policy interventions across Utah‚Äôs criminal justice and social provisioning system.
